Brundtland is a member of the Council of Women World Leaders, an international network of current and former women presidents and prime ministers whose mission is to mobilize collective action on issues of critical importance to women and equitable development.
'Members'. Council of Women World Leaders.
Brundtland is also a member of the Club of Madrid, an independent organization of former leaders of democratic states, which works to strengthen democratic governance and leadership.
'Brundtland, Gro Harlem'. Club de Madrid.
Brundtland is a founding member of The Elders, a group of world leaders originally convened by Nelson Mandela, Graça Machel and Desmond Tutu in order to tackle some of the world's toughest problems.
'Gro Harlem Brundtland'. The Elders.
She was appointed Deputy Chair of the group in 2013 and was succeeded in this role by Ban Ki-moon and Graça Machel in 2018.

roles: Co-chair of the WHO Global Preparedness Monitoring Board
supporting_quotes: In 2019, Brundtland served as co-chair with the WHO Global Preparedness Monitoring Board.

She became the first female prime minister of Norway on 4 February 1981, but left office on 14 October 1981;
She returned as prime minister on 9 May 1986 and served until 16 October 1989.
She finally returned for her third term on 3 November 1990.
After her surprise resignation as prime minister in 1996,
